newsArray.title: Sri Lanka fined for slow over-rate against South Africa
newsArray.content: Sri Lanka has been fined 10% of their match fee for maintaining a slow over-rate against South Africa in Match 4 of the ICC Men‚Äôs Cricket World Cup on Saturday. Javagal Srinath of the Emirates ICC Elite Panel of Match Referees imposed the sanction after Dasun Shanaka‚Äôs side was ruled to be 2 over(s) short of the target after time allowances were taken into consideration. In accordance with Article 2.22 of the ICC Code of Conduct for Players and Player Support Personnel, which relates to minimum over-rate offences, players are fined 5% of their match fees for every over if their side fails to bowl in the allotted time. Dasun Shanaka pleaded guilty to the offence and accepted the proposed sanction, so there was no need for a formal hearing. On-field umpires Richard Illingworth and Shahid Saikat, third umpire Michael Gough and fourth umpire Alex Wharf levelled the charge.

newsArray.title: Sri Lanka should take heart from Proteas bashing
newsArray.content: Sri Lanka whose bowlers were put to the sword by South Africa‚Äôs batsmen in their opening World Cup match at Delhi should not be disheartened from the pummelling they received at the hands of Quinton de Kock, Rassie van der Dussen and Aidan Markram, but use that experience to improve their bowling skills on flat surfaces which they will come across during their remaining matches of the tournament. The manner in which Markram batted showed that he was in a totally different plane to the rest of the batsmen. He was in such sublime form that any bowling attack would have found it difficult to curb his stroke play. Markram was the first to admit that it was a day where nothing could go wrong for him. ‚ÄúWhen it‚Äôs your day, try to cash in and really make it count,‚Äù he said at the post-match media conference. ‚ÄúLuckily, tonight, balls hit gaps. I mean, they don‚Äôt always hit gaps. And it could be a different story, but yeah thankful it worked out that way and again it was a really good pitch so that definitely assisted.‚Äù Cricketers usually experience that kind of feeling during their careers and on Saturday it was Markram‚Äôs day. He raced away to the fastest hundred by anyone at a World Cup off 49 balls and South Africa to the highest ever total in a World Cup game ‚Äì 428-5. It is nothing to be ashamed of that South Africa scored as many against an inexperienced Sri Lankan bowling attack. South Africa came to the World Cup having hammered Australia for 416-5 in an ODI played at the Centurion where they won by 164 runs less than a month ago. The Australian bowlers who were taken to task were Josh Hazlewood, Marcus Stoinis, Adam Zampa, Michael Nesser and Nathan Ellis. The day before the match Sri Lanka head Coach Chris Silverwood having looked at the Delhi pitch said that it was belter, and it proved so. A total of 754 runs were scored on it surpassing the previous highest aggregate at a World Cup match of 714 between Australia and Bangladesh at Nottingham in 2019. This sort of assault on the Sri Lankan bowlers cannot be ruled out in future matches for as compared to the rest of the nine teams in the competition, Sri Lanka has the least experienced bowling line-up. They sorely missed Wanindu Hasaranga, Dushmantha Chameera and Maheesh Theekshana who was in the dugout watching the carnage that was taking place before him. Theekshana could come into the team for Sri Lanka‚Äôs next match against Pakistan at Hyderabad on Tuesday and lend a little bit of experience to what one could describe as an uncooked bowling attack. The four frontline bowlers picked for the match ‚Äì Rajitha, Madushanka, Pathirana and Wellalage had a total of 59 ODIs and 79 wickets between them. Against such an inexperienced line-up any team on a surface like the one at Delhi would have made merry. It is certainly a big headache for the coaching staff to strategize on how this bowling could contain or take wickets against an opposition if there is no help at all from the wicket. Sri Lanka didn‚Äôt have luck on their side either because a couple of half chances and a run out were missed. When your bowling is weak, fielding comes into play in a big way to compensate for it and half chances like the ones that Sri Lanka missed out on should have been taken to encourage the bowling unit. Sri Lanka certainly didn‚Äôt have a chance of chasing down South Africa‚Äôs massive total but at least they made an effort to put up a decent show with the bat and reach 326. If not for the difference in the wickets lost Sri Lanka could have given South Africa a good run. At the end of 40 overs they were on par with South Africa at 291-8 as against 291-3, the only difference being the loss of wickets. Kusal Mendis, the way he began, looked as if he was determined to chase after Markram‚Äôs record-breaking century. But it was too good to last and once he succumbed, the chase simply lost its momentum and it boiled down to how well Sri Lanka could utilise the remaining overs ‚Äì there were 37 left. They managed to last 32, which raises the question why they are unable to consume their full quota of 50. This is the third successive occasion in this World Cup that Sri Lanka has failed to bat out their full quota, the first two being in the warm-up games. That is one area Sri Lanka needs to really work on for it‚Äôs a cardinal sin in ODI cricket not to use your full quota. One encouraging factor to emerge from the match was that Charith Asalanka and skipper Dasun Shanaka managed to spend time in the middle to score fifties. Asalanka has proved time and again that he is rock solid in the middle-order lending that stability which the team needs. As for Shanaka, he could breathe a bit easy having finally managed to come up with a half-century after failures in his past 17 innings. He was not at his best but the innings would give him a world of good for his confidence for the rest of the tournament.

newsArray.title: India gifted Asian Games cricket gold over Afghanistan by ranking rule
newsArray.content: Gifted an armchair ride by Asian Games organisers, India has taken gold in men‚Äôs cricket as the rain-hit T20 final against Afghanistan was decided by the superpower‚Äôs superior global ranking. Afghanistan, ranked 10th in the ICC‚Äôs T20 rankings versus world number one India, was left with silver on Saturday and powerless to do anything about it after rain halted the match when they were 112 for five after 18.2 overs of the first innings. With India unable to bat a minimum of five overs, and play was abandoned soon after 5 p.m. local time (09:00 GMT), leaving Ruturaj Gaikwad‚Äôs team to celebrate victory by default. Deciding results based purely on teams‚Äô global rankings is almost unheard of in cricket, let alone for finals in major tournaments. Most allow spare days so that deciders can be completed if rain washes out play in the original match. If no spare days are provided, a winner is generally declared via tie-breaking criteria based on a team‚Äôs performances within the tournament they are playing. Twenty20 cricket has been played at the Asian Games twice before, at Guangzhou 2010 and Incheon 2014, with Bangladesh and then Sri Lanka crowned men‚Äôs winners. Afghanistan were runners-up both times, but India did not take part. The rankings rule also helped India‚Äôs gold medal-winning women‚Äôs team reach the semifinals after rain washed out their quarterfinal against Malaysia. India went on to beat Sri Lanka by 19 runs to be crowned women‚Äôs champions last week. Rain also hit the men‚Äôs bronze medal playoff won by Bangladesh against Pakistan but held off long enough to at least ensure a contest between the teams.

newsArray.title: Marsh grasses and Kohli flowers: India take game one
creator: Greg Baum
newsArray.description: Australia will never know what might have happened if Mitch Marsh had taken a difficult catch from Virat Kohli. But afterwards, he stole the match away from them.
newsArray.content: For as long as Virat Kohli‚Äôs popped top-edged pull from Josh Hazlewood hung in the steamy Chepauk air, so did Australia‚Äôs suddenly alive prospects of upsetting India in this World Cup opener, making a distant memory of their pre-tournament woes and perhaps supplanting the host as the team to beat. It had happened here before. The crowd knew it; they gasped. If ‚Äì when ‚Äì the catch was taken, it would leave India, already reeling from a trio of top-order ducks, 4/20 in what would surely then be a vain pursuit of Australia‚Äôs admittedly modest 199. Its batting order this night was not as dependably deep as in recent years. But wicketkeeper Alex Carey and square leg Mitch Marsh, sprinting towards each other, had no time to establish right of way and a sliding Marsh dropped the catch. In the compounding way of these things, both had earlier made ducks on personally miserable nights. Hazlewood blamed no one. ‚ÄúI think it was Mitch‚Äôs catch and Carey got quite close in the end and might have just put Mitch off,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a dropped catch, one of those things that happened.‚Äù It‚Äôs not empirically demonstrable, of course, that this was the match in a moment. Hazlewood pooh-poohed the idea. ‚ÄúIt was quite early,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe still felt that new ball ‚Äì it was doing enough, whether it was in the air or off the wicket, (and) we knew that spin was going to be tough to play. Maybe not as tough as during the day. We certainly felt in the game for quite a while until the partnership grew and grew. They sort of batted us out of it.‚Äù Mitch Marsh after being dismissed. Credit: Getty Indeed, the reprieved Kohli was as mistake-free as only he can be ‚Äì and KL Rahul fell in alongside him ‚Äì although he eventually fell for a textbook 85. By then, he and Rahul had added 165 and paced their country to the threshold of a four-wicket victory. Rahul finished the match by handsomely driving Australian captain Pat Cummins over long off for six to strand himself on 97 not out, whereupon non-striker Hardik Pandya shook his head at the bittersweetness of it all. In the dewy monsoonal night, Australia‚Äôs makeshift spin pair Adam Zampa and Glenn Maxwell were unable to replicate the mesmerising mastery of India‚Äôs trio spinners in the afternoon. Moreover, the Indian bowlers as a team ‚Äì their quicks merit honourable mentions here, too ‚Äì had so restrained Australia that the batsmen in their turn could make haste slowly, and did. Rahul goes big. Credit: AP It made for a peculiarly downbeat game for these best of rivals, paling beside the pyrotechnics of the first three days. Australia‚Äôs 199 was fewer than South Africa had made in their last 20 overs against Sri Lanka in Delhi the night before. Admittedly, this was apples and pears ‚Äì Sri Lanka‚Äôs attack was feeble ‚Äì but this World Cup appears to be there for the bold to take. South Africa are Australia‚Äôs next opponent. The crowd figure was of a piece with the action. At 32,351, it was well short of the stadium‚Äôs 40,000 capacity. Not yet in the tournament has a stadium been full, though notionally every match has sold out. Cricket might be a religion in this country, but it belongs to an exclusive brethren. But there‚Äôs no mystery; it‚Äôs down to chronic disorganisation. Other than that 12-ball, three-wicket counterpunch at the top of India‚Äôs innings, this was a largely forgettable opening sally for Australia, in which their recent shortcomings were again exposed: inability to accelerate with the bat and lack of penetration in spin bowling. Hazlewood refuted the idea that the spin department was lacking, saying he regarded Maxwell in India as a frontliner, but conditions had militated against rather than for them this day. Australia, drawing on previous experience, had batted first in the expectation that the pitch would die and batting would become harder as the day wore on, but instead found that was at its most challenging in the afternoon sun. ‚ÄúIt was as extreme as it gets,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt was probably a good examination to get first up, against the best spinners in the tournament. Hopefully, it‚Äôll get a bit easier from hereon in.‚Äù From the early loss of Marsh, Australia always felt a wicket over budget. With verifiable batting only to No.7, they did not have the luxury of a wicket to throw away in the cause of a momentum-shifting blast as the Indian spinners wove their characteristic web around Australia. David Warner, Steve Smith and Marnus Labuschagne all toiled in vain to force the pace. When the squeeze became too much, Australia lost 5/30. Smith alone could be said to have been dismissed by an unplayable ball, a Ravindra Jadeja jaffa, straightening past his outside to bowl him. The Indian tweakers are a true ensemble too, each a virtuoso in a different key of their craft. In their collective 30 overs, they took 6/94. Loading If anything, the Australians‚Äô line-up was too orthodox for an era in which 50-over cricket has become a lengthier form of the T20 format. In theory, Marcus Stoinis would change that complexion, and Travis Head, too, if he can get a doctor‚Äôs certificate in time. If ever Australia needed a hand, it‚Äôs his broken one. India‚Äôs innings began as if the sun had gone to their heads. Ishan Kishan and Shreyas Iyer were caught from extravagant drives and captain Rohit Sharma was trapped by a break-back from Josh Hazlewood and after 12 balls, India were 3/2. If Australia had short-changed themselves when batting, suddenly they were trading in a whole new currency. But once Kohli was grassed and he and Rahul settled into their task, and as the dew fell and the crowd rose, Australia‚Äôs fangs were slowly drawn. None of the bowlers were embarrassed, but none notably troubled the Indian pair as their partnership grew. Australia prides itself on being a tournament team, rising to occasions, growing into the event. They will need to be now. They have at least eight more games at seven other venues. They know all will differ slightly, which means the Australians will have to adapt their tactics and outlook as they go. That includes the wisdom of batting first and the notion of what constitutes a playable score. ‚ÄúWe might come up against these conditions again throughout those eight games,‚Äù said Hazlewood. ‚ÄúWe might have to reassess and say 260 is a good score rather than 300 plus as we‚Äôve seen on some other grounds.‚Äù News, results and expert analysis from the weekend of sport sent every Monday. newsArray.title: Rain Stays Away in Chennai As India Beat Australia By Six Wickets in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023
newsArray.description: The Men in Blue begin their sojourn in the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 against Australia. But rainfall in the past few days in Chennai has posed a threat to this game? Will rain affect this match? Read below to get updates about Chennai weather.
newsArray.content: Despite rains in Chennai preceding the match, fortunately it didn't interrupt the game at any point. A complete was possible and in the end, India came out victorious beating Australia in their opening match of the campaign riding on the emphatic performances from KL Rahul and Virat Kohli. There has been no rain so far as the India vs Australia match in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 has gotten underway, with a bright sunny, sky up above. Players and fans would hope that this remains throughout and there is no rain interrupting this contest. The sun is out and the MA Chidambaram Stadium looks set to host this high-voltage contest. There has been no rain so far with less than two hours to go for the game to begin. Current Scenes of Chennai Stadium, The weather Looks Sunny üåà #INDvsAUS pic.twitter.com/IqUYcyDryf ‚Äî Haroon üèèüå† (@HaroonM33120350) October 8, 2023 The weather gods have been kind towards fans today as there has been no sign of rain in Chennai ahead of the India vs Australia match. It has rained in the city in the past few days which has posed a threat over this match as well. The weather at the moment is pretty sunny with patchy clouds. Sunny weather,patchy clouds #Chennai #IndvsAus pic.twitter.com/LlWCDk7eQ5 ‚Äî Chennai Weather-Raja Ramasamy (@chennaiweather) October 8, 2023 Good news for fans! There's no sign of rain in Chepauk so far hours before the India vs Australia ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 contest. Chennai has been witnessing unpredictable weather in the past few days but it is bright and sunny at the moment. Fans would hope the weather stays this way! It's bright & sunny at Chepauk. [Vimal Kumar] - Great news for cricket fans. pic.twitter.com/lnEHyNxSLb ‚Äî Johns. (@CricCrazyJohns) October 8, 2023 The MA Chidambaram Stadium in Chennai is set to host India's first match of the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023, against mighty Australia on October 8. The contest has been talked about a lot with home fans expecting India to put up a good show and get off to a winning start to their ICC Men's Cricket World Cup 2023 campaign. India recently did beat Australia in an ODI series and although that would give the Men in Blue some confidence, Rohit Sharma and his team would be well aware of how dangerous Australia really can be if their players fire in unison. However, there remains a rain threat that looms large over this contest in Chennai. India vs Australia ICC Cricket World Cup 2023, Chennai Weather Report: Check Out Rain Forecast and Pitch Report at M Chidambaram Stadium. The capital city has been experiencing inconsistent weather in the past few days and it casts a shadow of uncertainty over this high-octane match as well. An update on the Chennai weather provided by popular cricket commentator Harsha Bhogle might be a cause of worry for fans, who would have an eye on the sky as well today. Bhogle had taken to his official account on X, formerly Twitter, and wrote, "Bucketing down in Chennai...Very dark." There remains a possibility of this match being affected by rain. According to the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD), there is a 12-17% probability of rainfall in Chennai during the match hours. Moreover, there would be cloudy skies during the game. Fans would hope that should there be rain, it merely disrupts the contest for a while rather than washing it out. India could not have any warm-up match leading upto this match with rain washing out both their matches--against England and Netherlands. The Men in Blue would hope that the weather is fine when they take on Australia in this highly-anticipated CWC 2023 contest.

First they squeezed Australia with the spinners crumbling them for only 199 runs and then during the chase, despite being in a dire situation, powered themselves out of it riding on the brilliant knocks of Virat Kohli and KL Rahul and won the match registering first points on the table. Sachin Tendulkar, Virender Sehwag, Irfan Pathan were elated by the performance and took to social media to react. I was surprised to see Australia bat first after winning the toss. newsArray.title: Might have to change combinations as per different conditions: Rohit Sharma
newsArray.description: However, Rohit heaved a sigh of relief after India recovered from a precarious 2/3 to beat Australia by six wickets and begin their campaign in the showpiece on a positive note. CHENNAI: Rohit Sharma on Sunday admitted that the biggest challenge in front of his side would be to play in different conditions, and the Indian captain also did not rule out making changes in team combinations to suit the demands of a particular venue. However, Rohit heaved a sigh of relief after India recovered from a precarious 2/3 to beat Australia by six wickets and begin their campaign in the showpiece on a positive note. "That will be the biggest challenge moving forward because we will play in different conditions. (We) might have to change combinations too and as a team we are prepared to do that," said Rohit during the post-match presentation. Rohit was particularly pleased with the team's fielding. "Good feeling to come out on top. Magnificent, especially the fielding. The fielding was something we really put our effort on. It was a great effort. In conditions like this it can be tough sometimes. We knew there would be assistance for everyone. Seamers got reverse, spinners bowled in nice areas. All in all a great effort," he said. Rohit was one of the three top-order India batters to get out for a duck, and the skipper admitted to being nervous with the home team reeling at 2/3 in the second over. "Yes I was (nervous) to be honest. You don't want to start like that when chasing a target. Credit to Australia, but some loose shots there as well. But that happens, you want to get off the mark and score quickly in the powerplay." "But hats off to Virat and KL - the way they stuck out there to create a match-winning partnership," Rohit said. Australian captain Pat Cummins felt his team was 50 runs short of what could have been a challenging total. "At least 50-odd. It was tough, trying to defend anything under 200. It was a really good bowling attack and their spinners made it tough work out there. "I wasn't too upset (with just two spinners), we had 20 overs of spin but some more runs on the board would have made the difference," Cummins said. When asked about the drop catch by Mitchell Marsh early on in Kohli's innings, Cummins said, "I have already forgotten about it, it happens, 4/10 would have been a dream start. "Just one game out of nine, not too much to ponder about but there are some areas we need to get better." Arriving at the crease with his team in a spot of bother, Rahul said Kohli had advised him to play out that difficult period like they do in Test cricket. "Quite honestly, there weren't a lot of conversations (with Kohli). I thought I'd get a good shower and get a break. I was just trying to get my breath back." "Virat said there's a bit in the wicket, so play like Test cricket for a while. There was a bit of help for the pacers with the new ball, and then the spinners also," Rahul said. "In the last 15-20 overs, dew played a part and that helped quite a bit. The ball also skidded on better. However, it was a bit two-paced, it wasn't the easiest of wickets to bat on and it wasn't flat as well." "It was a good cricket wicket, bit for the batters and the bowlers. That's what you get in the south of India, especially in Chennai.

newsArray.title: Sri Lanka fined for slow over-rate against South Africa
newsArray.content: Sri Lanka has been fined 10% of their match fee for maintaining a slow over-rate against South Africa in Match 4 of the ICC Men‚Äôs Cricket World Cup on Saturday. Javagal Srinath of the Emirates ICC Elite Panel of Match Referees imposed the sanction after Dasun Shanaka‚Äôs side was ruled to be 2 over(s) short of the target after time allowances were taken into consideration. In accordance with Article 2.22 of the ICC Code of Conduct for Players and Player Support Personnel, which relates to minimum over-rate offences, players are fined 5% of their match fees for every over if their side fails to bowl in the allotted time. Dasun Shanaka pleaded guilty to the offence and accepted the proposed sanction, so there was no need for a formal hearing. On-field umpires Richard Illingworth and Shahid Saikat, third umpire Michael Gough and fourth umpire Alex Wharf levelled the charge.

newsArray.title: Sri Lanka should take heart from Proteas bashing
newsArray.content: Sri Lanka whose bowlers were put to the sword by South Africa‚Äôs batsmen in their opening World Cup match at Delhi should not be disheartened from the pummelling they received at the hands of Quinton de Kock, Rassie van der Dussen and Aidan Markram, but use that experience to improve their bowling skills on flat surfaces which they will come across during their remaining matches of the tournament. The manner in which Markram batted showed that he was in a totally different plane to the rest of the batsmen. He was in such sublime form that any bowling attack would have found it difficult to curb his stroke play. Markram was the first to admit that it was a day where nothing could go wrong for him. ‚ÄúWhen it‚Äôs your day, try to cash in and really make it count,‚Äù he said at the post-match media conference. ‚ÄúLuckily, tonight, balls hit gaps. I mean, they don‚Äôt always hit gaps. And it could be a different story, but yeah thankful it worked out that way and again it was a really good pitch so that definitely assisted.‚Äù Cricketers usually experience that kind of feeling during their careers and on Saturday it was Markram‚Äôs day. He raced away to the fastest hundred by anyone at a World Cup off 49 balls and South Africa to the highest ever total in a World Cup game ‚Äì 428-5. It is nothing to be ashamed of that South Africa scored as many against an inexperienced Sri Lankan bowling attack. South Africa came to the World Cup having hammered Australia for 416-5 in an ODI played at the Centurion where they won by 164 runs less than a month ago. The Australian bowlers who were taken to task were Josh Hazlewood, Marcus Stoinis, Adam Zampa, Michael Nesser and Nathan Ellis. The day before the match Sri Lanka head Coach Chris Silverwood having looked at the Delhi pitch said that it was belter, and it proved so. A total of 754 runs were scored on it surpassing the previous highest aggregate at a World Cup match of 714 between Australia and Bangladesh at Nottingham in 2019. This sort of assault on the Sri Lankan bowlers cannot be ruled out in future matches for as compared to the rest of the nine teams in the competition, Sri Lanka has the least experienced bowling line-up. They sorely missed Wanindu Hasaranga, Dushmantha Chameera and Maheesh Theekshana who was in the dugout watching the carnage that was taking place before him. Theekshana could come into the team for Sri Lanka‚Äôs next match against Pakistan at Hyderabad on Tuesday and lend a little bit of experience to what one could describe as an uncooked bowling attack. The four frontline bowlers picked for the match ‚Äì Rajitha, Madushanka, Pathirana and Wellalage had a total of 59 ODIs and 79 wickets between them. Against such an inexperienced line-up any team on a surface like the one at Delhi would have made merry. It is certainly a big headache for the coaching staff to strategize on how this bowling could contain or take wickets against an opposition if there is no help at all from the wicket. Sri Lanka didn‚Äôt have luck on their side either because a couple of half chances and a run out were missed. When your bowling is weak, fielding comes into play in a big way to compensate for it and half chances like the ones that Sri Lanka missed out on should have been taken to encourage the bowling unit. Sri Lanka certainly didn‚Äôt have a chance of chasing down South Africa‚Äôs massive total but at least they made an effort to put up a decent show with the bat and reach 326. If not for the difference in the wickets lost Sri Lanka could have given South Africa a good run. At the end of 40 overs they were on par with South Africa at 291-8 as against 291-3, the only difference being the loss of wickets. Kusal Mendis, the way he began, looked as if he was determined to chase after Markram‚Äôs record-breaking century. But it was too good to last and once he succumbed, the chase simply lost its momentum and it boiled down to how well Sri Lanka could utilise the remaining overs ‚Äì there were 37 left. They managed to last 32, which raises the question why they are unable to consume their full quota of 50. This is the third successive occasion in this World Cup that Sri Lanka has failed to bat out their full quota, the first two being in the warm-up games. That is one area Sri Lanka needs to really work on for it‚Äôs a cardinal sin in ODI cricket not to use your full quota. One encouraging factor to emerge from the match was that Charith Asalanka and skipper Dasun Shanaka managed to spend time in the middle to score fifties. Asalanka has proved time and again that he is rock solid in the middle-order lending that stability which the team needs. As for Shanaka, he could breathe a bit easy having finally managed to come up with a half-century after failures in his past 17 innings. He was not at his best but the innings would give him a world of good for his confidence for the rest of the tournament.

newsArray.title: India gifted Asian Games cricket gold over Afghanistan by ranking rule
newsArray.content: Gifted an armchair ride by Asian Games organisers, India has taken gold in men‚Äôs cricket as the rain-hit T20 final against Afghanistan was decided by the superpower‚Äôs superior global ranking. Afghanistan, ranked 10th in the ICC‚Äôs T20 rankings versus world number one India, was left with silver on Saturday and powerless to do anything about it after rain halted the match when they were 112 for five after 18.2 overs of the first innings. With India unable to bat a minimum of five overs, and play was abandoned soon after 5 p.m. local time (09:00 GMT), leaving Ruturaj Gaikwad‚Äôs team to celebrate victory by default. Deciding results based purely on teams‚Äô global rankings is almost unheard of in cricket, let alone for finals in major tournaments. Most allow spare days so that deciders can be completed if rain washes out play in the original match. If no spare days are provided, a winner is generally declared via tie-breaking criteria based on a team‚Äôs performances within the tournament they are playing. Twenty20 cricket has been played at the Asian Games twice before, at Guangzhou 2010 and Incheon 2014, with Bangladesh and then Sri Lanka crowned men‚Äôs winners. Afghanistan were runners-up both times, but India did not take part. The rankings rule also helped India‚Äôs gold medal-winning women‚Äôs team reach the semifinals after rain washed out their quarterfinal against Malaysia. India went on to beat Sri Lanka by 19 runs to be crowned women‚Äôs champions last week. Rain also hit the men‚Äôs bronze medal playoff won by Bangladesh against Pakistan but held off long enough to at least ensure a contest between the teams.

newsArray.title: Marsh grasses and Kohli flowers: India take game one
creator: Greg Baum
newsArray.description: Australia will never know what might have happened if Mitch Marsh had taken a difficult catch from Virat Kohli. But afterwards, he stole the match away from them.
newsArray.content: For as long as Virat Kohli‚Äôs popped top-edged pull from Josh Hazlewood hung in the steamy Chepauk air, so did Australia‚Äôs suddenly alive prospects of upsetting India in this World Cup opener, making a distant memory of their pre-tournament woes and perhaps supplanting the host as the team to beat. It had happened here before. The crowd knew it; they gasped. If ‚Äì when ‚Äì the catch was taken, it would leave India, already reeling from a trio of top-order ducks, 4/20 in what would surely then be a vain pursuit of Australia‚Äôs admittedly modest 199. Its batting order this night was not as dependably deep as in recent years. But wicketkeeper Alex Carey and square leg Mitch Marsh, sprinting towards each other, had no time to establish right of way and a sliding Marsh dropped the catch. In the compounding way of these things, both had earlier made ducks on personally miserable nights. Hazlewood blamed no one. ‚ÄúI think it was Mitch‚Äôs catch and Carey got quite close in the end and might have just put Mitch off,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a dropped catch, one of those things that happened.‚Äù It‚Äôs not empirically demonstrable, of course, that this was the match in a moment. Hazlewood pooh-poohed the idea. ‚ÄúIt was quite early,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe still felt that new ball ‚Äì it was doing enough, whether it was in the air or off the wicket, (and) we knew that spin was going to be tough to play. Maybe not as tough as during the day. We certainly felt in the game for quite a while until the partnership grew and grew. They sort of batted us out of it.‚Äù Mitch Marsh after being dismissed. Credit: Getty Indeed, the reprieved Kohli was as mistake-free as only he can be ‚Äì and KL Rahul fell in alongside him ‚Äì although he eventually fell for a textbook 85. By then, he and Rahul had added 165 and paced their country to the threshold of a four-wicket victory. Rahul finished the match by handsomely driving Australian captain Pat Cummins over long off for six to strand himself on 97 not out, whereupon non-striker Hardik Pandya shook his head at the bittersweetness of it all. In the dewy monsoonal night, Australia‚Äôs makeshift spin pair Adam Zampa and Glenn Maxwell were unable to replicate the mesmerising mastery of India‚Äôs trio spinners in the afternoon. Moreover, the Indian bowlers as a team ‚Äì their quicks merit honourable mentions here, too ‚Äì had so restrained Australia that the batsmen in their turn could make haste slowly, and did. Rahul goes big. Credit: AP It made for a peculiarly downbeat game for these best of rivals, paling beside the pyrotechnics of the first three days. Australia‚Äôs 199 was fewer than South Africa had made in their last 20 overs against Sri Lanka in Delhi the night before. Admittedly, this was apples and pears ‚Äì Sri Lanka‚Äôs attack was feeble ‚Äì but this World Cup appears to be there for the bold to take. South Africa are Australia‚Äôs next opponent. The crowd figure was of a piece with the action. At 32,351, it was well short of the stadium‚Äôs 40,000 capacity. Not yet in the tournament has a stadium been full, though notionally every match has sold out. Cricket might be a religion in this country, but it belongs to an exclusive brethren. But there‚Äôs no mystery; it‚Äôs down to chronic disorganisation. Other than that 12-ball, three-wicket counterpunch at the top of India‚Äôs innings, this was a largely forgettable opening sally for Australia, in which their recent shortcomings were again exposed: inability to accelerate with the bat and lack of penetration in spin bowling. Hazlewood refuted the idea that the spin department was lacking, saying he regarded Maxwell in India as a frontliner, but conditions had militated against rather than for them this day. Australia, drawing on previous experience, had batted first in the expectation that the pitch would die and batting would become harder as the day wore on, but instead found that was at its most challenging in the afternoon sun. ‚ÄúIt was as extreme as it gets,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt was probably a good examination to get first up, against the best spinners in the tournament. Hopefully, it‚Äôll get a bit easier from hereon in.‚Äù From the early loss of Marsh, Australia always felt a wicket over budget. With verifiable batting only to No.7, they did not have the luxury of a wicket to throw away in the cause of a momentum-shifting blast as the Indian spinners wove their characteristic web around Australia. David Warner, Steve Smith and Marnus Labuschagne all toiled in vain to force the pace. When the squeeze became too much, Australia lost 5/30. Smith alone could be said to have been dismissed by an unplayable ball, a Ravindra Jadeja jaffa, straightening past his outside to bowl him. The Indian tweakers are a true ensemble too, each a virtuoso in a different key of their craft. In their collective 30 overs, they took 6/94. Loading If anything, the Australians‚Äô line-up was too orthodox for an era in which 50-over cricket has become a lengthier form of the T20 format. In theory, Marcus Stoinis would change that complexion, and Travis Head, too, if he can get a doctor‚Äôs certificate in time. If ever Australia needed a hand, it‚Äôs his broken one. India‚Äôs innings began as if the sun had gone to their heads. Ishan Kishan and Shreyas Iyer were caught from extravagant drives and captain Rohit Sharma was trapped by a break-back from Josh Hazlewood and after 12 balls, India were 3/2. If Australia had short-changed themselves when batting, suddenly they were trading in a whole new currency. But once Kohli was grassed and he and Rahul settled into their task, and as the dew fell and the crowd rose, Australia‚Äôs fangs were slowly drawn. None of the bowlers were embarrassed, but none notably troubled the Indian pair as their partnership grew. Australia prides itself on being a tournament team, rising to occasions, growing into the event. They will need to be now. They have at least eight more games at seven other venues. They know all will differ slightly, which means the Australians will have to adapt their tactics and outlook as they go. That includes the wisdom of batting first and the notion of what constitutes a playable score. ‚ÄúWe might come up against these conditions again throughout those eight games,‚Äù said Hazlewood. ‚ÄúWe might have to reassess and say 260 is a good score rather than 300 plus as we‚Äôve seen on some other grounds.‚Äù News, results and expert analysis from the weekend of sport sent every Monday. newsArray.title: Rain Stays Away in Chennai As India Beat Australia By Six Wickets in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023
newsArray.description: The Men in Blue begin their sojourn in the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 against Australia. But rainfall in the past few days in Chennai has posed a threat to this game? Will rain affect this match? Read below to get updates about Chennai weather.
newsArray.content: Despite rains in Chennai preceding the match, fortunately it didn't interrupt the game at any point. A complete was possible and in the end, India came out victorious beating Australia in their opening match of the campaign riding on the emphatic performances from KL Rahul and Virat Kohli. There has been no rain so far as the India vs Australia match in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 has gotten underway, with a bright sunny, sky up above. Players and fans would hope that this remains throughout and there is no rain interrupting this contest. The sun is out and the MA Chidambaram Stadium looks set to host this high-voltage contest. There has been no rain so far with less than two hours to go for the game to begin. Current Scenes of Chennai Stadium, The weather Looks Sunny üåà #INDvsAUS pic.twitter.com/IqUYcyDryf ‚Äî Haroon üèèüå† (@HaroonM33120350) October 8, 2023 The weather gods have been kind towards fans today as there has been no sign of rain in Chennai ahead of the India vs Australia match. It has rained in the city in the past few days which has posed a threat over this match as well. The weather at the moment is pretty sunny with patchy clouds. Sunny weather,patchy clouds #Chennai #IndvsAus pic.twitter.com/LlWCDk7eQ5 ‚Äî Chennai Weather-Raja Ramasamy (@chennaiweather) October 8, 2023 Good news for fans! There's no sign of rain in Chepauk so far hours before the India vs Australia ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 contest. Chennai has been witnessing unpredictable weather in the past few days but it is bright and sunny at the moment. Fans would hope the weather stays this way! It's bright & sunny at Chepauk. [Vimal Kumar] - Great news for cricket fans. pic.twitter.com/lnEHyNxSLb ‚Äî Johns. (@CricCrazyJohns) October 8, 2023 The MA Chidambaram Stadium in Chennai is set to host India's first match of the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023, against mighty Australia on October 8. The contest has been talked about a lot with home fans expecting India to put up a good show and get off to a winning start to their ICC Men's Cricket World Cup 2023 campaign. India recently did beat Australia in an ODI series and although that would give the Men in Blue some confidence, Rohit Sharma and his team would be well aware of how dangerous Australia really can be if their players fire in unison. However, there remains a rain threat that looms large over this contest in Chennai. India vs Australia ICC Cricket World Cup 2023, Chennai Weather Report: Check Out Rain Forecast and Pitch Report at M Chidambaram Stadium. The capital city has been experiencing inconsistent weather in the past few days and it casts a shadow of uncertainty over this high-octane match as well. An update on the Chennai weather provided by popular cricket commentator Harsha Bhogle might be a cause of worry for fans, who would have an eye on the sky as well today. Bhogle had taken to his official account on X, formerly Twitter, and wrote, "Bucketing down in Chennai...Very dark." There remains a possibility of this match being affected by rain. According to the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD), there is a 12-17% probability of rainfall in Chennai during the match hours. Moreover, there would be cloudy skies during the game. Fans would hope that should there be rain, it merely disrupts the contest for a while rather than washing it out. India could not have any warm-up match leading upto this match with rain washing out both their matches--against England and Netherlands. The Men in Blue would hope that the weather is fine when they take on Australia in this highly-anticipated CWC 2023 contest.

newsArray.title: Might have to change combinations as per different conditions: Rohit Sharma
newsArray.description: However, Rohit heaved a sigh of relief after India recovered from a precarious 2/3 to beat Australia by six wickets and begin their campaign in the showpiece on a positive note. CHENNAI: Rohit Sharma on Sunday admitted that the biggest challenge in front of his side would be to play in different conditions, and the Indian captain also did not rule out making changes in team combinations to suit the demands of a particular venue. However, Rohit heaved a sigh of relief after India recovered from a precarious 2/3 to beat Australia by six wickets and begin their campaign in the showpiece on a positive note. "That will be the biggest challenge moving forward because we will play in different conditions. (We) might have to change combinations too and as a team we are prepared to do that," said Rohit during the post-match presentation. Rohit was particularly pleased with the team's fielding. "Good feeling to come out on top. Magnificent, especially the fielding. The fielding was something we really put our effort on. It was a great effort. In conditions like this it can be tough sometimes. We knew there would be assistance for everyone. Seamers got reverse, spinners bowled in nice areas. All in all a great effort," he said. Rohit was one of the three top-order India batters to get out for a duck, and the skipper admitted to being nervous with the home team reeling at 2/3 in the second over. "Yes I was (nervous) to be honest. You don't want to start like that when chasing a target. Credit to Australia, but some loose shots there as well. But that happens, you want to get off the mark and score quickly in the powerplay." "But hats off to Virat and KL - the way they stuck out there to create a match-winning partnership," Rohit said. Australian captain Pat Cummins felt his team was 50 runs short of what could have been a challenging total. "At least 50-odd. It was tough, trying to defend anything under 200. It was a really good bowling attack and their spinners made it tough work out there. "I wasn't too upset (with just two spinners), we had 20 overs of spin but some more runs on the board would have made the difference," Cummins said. When asked about the drop catch by Mitchell Marsh early on in Kohli's innings, Cummins said, "I have already forgotten about it, it happens, 4/10 would have been a dream start. "Just one game out of nine, not too much to ponder about but there are some areas we need to get better." Arriving at the crease with his team in a spot of bother, Rahul said Kohli had advised him to play out that difficult period like they do in Test cricket. "Quite honestly, there weren't a lot of conversations (with Kohli). I thought I'd get a good shower and get a break. I was just trying to get my breath back." "Virat said there's a bit in the wicket, so play like Test cricket for a while. There was a bit of help for the pacers with the new ball, and then the spinners also," Rahul said. "In the last 15-20 overs, dew played a part and that helped quite a bit. The ball also skidded on better. However, it was a bit two-paced, it wasn't the easiest of wickets to bat on and it wasn't flat as well." "It was a good cricket wicket, bit for the batters and the bowlers. That's what you get in the south of India, especially in Chennai.

newsArray.title: Sri Lanka fined for slow over-rate against South Africa
newsArray.content: Sri Lanka has been fined 10% of their match fee for maintaining a slow over-rate against South Africa in Match 4 of the ICC Men‚Äôs Cricket World Cup on Saturday. Javagal Srinath of the Emirates ICC Elite Panel of Match Referees imposed the sanction after Dasun Shanaka‚Äôs side was ruled to be 2 over(s) short of the target after time allowances were taken into consideration. In accordance with Article 2.22 of the ICC Code of Conduct for Players and Player Support Personnel, which relates to minimum over-rate offences, players are fined 5% of their match fees for every over if their side fails to bowl in the allotted time. Dasun Shanaka pleaded guilty to the offence and accepted the proposed sanction, so there was no need for a formal hearing. On-field umpires Richard Illingworth and Shahid Saikat, third umpire Michael Gough and fourth umpire Alex Wharf levelled the charge.

newsArray.title: Sri Lanka should take heart from Proteas bashing
newsArray.content: Sri Lanka whose bowlers were put to the sword by South Africa‚Äôs batsmen in their opening World Cup match at Delhi should not be disheartened from the pummelling they received at the hands of Quinton de Kock, Rassie van der Dussen and Aidan Markram, but use that experience to improve their bowling skills on flat surfaces which they will come across during their remaining matches of the tournament. The manner in which Markram batted showed that he was in a totally different plane to the rest of the batsmen. He was in such sublime form that any bowling attack would have found it difficult to curb his stroke play. Markram was the first to admit that it was a day where nothing could go wrong for him. ‚ÄúWhen it‚Äôs your day, try to cash in and really make it count,‚Äù he said at the post-match media conference. ‚ÄúLuckily, tonight, balls hit gaps. I mean, they don‚Äôt always hit gaps. And it could be a different story, but yeah thankful it worked out that way and again it was a really good pitch so that definitely assisted.‚Äù Cricketers usually experience that kind of feeling during their careers and on Saturday it was Markram‚Äôs day. He raced away to the fastest hundred by anyone at a World Cup off 49 balls and South Africa to the highest ever total in a World Cup game ‚Äì 428-5. It is nothing to be ashamed of that South Africa scored as many against an inexperienced Sri Lankan bowling attack. South Africa came to the World Cup having hammered Australia for 416-5 in an ODI played at the Centurion where they won by 164 runs less than a month ago. The Australian bowlers who were taken to task were Josh Hazlewood, Marcus Stoinis, Adam Zampa, Michael Nesser and Nathan Ellis. The day before the match Sri Lanka head Coach Chris Silverwood having looked at the Delhi pitch said that it was belter, and it proved so. A total of 754 runs were scored on it surpassing the previous highest aggregate at a World Cup match of 714 between Australia and Bangladesh at Nottingham in 2019. This sort of assault on the Sri Lankan bowlers cannot be ruled out in future matches for as compared to the rest of the nine teams in the competition, Sri Lanka has the least experienced bowling line-up. They sorely missed Wanindu Hasaranga, Dushmantha Chameera and Maheesh Theekshana who was in the dugout watching the carnage that was taking place before him. Theekshana could come into the team for Sri Lanka‚Äôs next match against Pakistan at Hyderabad on Tuesday and lend a little bit of experience to what one could describe as an uncooked bowling attack. The four frontline bowlers picked for the match ‚Äì Rajitha, Madushanka, Pathirana and Wellalage had a total of 59 ODIs and 79 wickets between them. Against such an inexperienced line-up any team on a surface like the one at Delhi would have made merry. It is certainly a big headache for the coaching staff to strategize on how this bowling could contain or take wickets against an opposition if there is no help at all from the wicket. Sri Lanka didn‚Äôt have luck on their side either because a couple of half chances and a run out were missed. When your bowling is weak, fielding comes into play in a big way to compensate for it and half chances like the ones that Sri Lanka missed out on should have been taken to encourage the bowling unit. Sri Lanka certainly didn‚Äôt have a chance of chasing down South Africa‚Äôs massive total but at least they made an effort to put up a decent show with the bat and reach 326. If not for the difference in the wickets lost Sri Lanka could have given South Africa a good run. At the end of 40 overs they were on par with South Africa at 291-8 as against 291-3, the only difference being the loss of wickets. Kusal Mendis, the way he began, looked as if he was determined to chase after Markram‚Äôs record-breaking century. But it was too good to last and once he succumbed, the chase simply lost its momentum and it boiled down to how well Sri Lanka could utilise the remaining overs ‚Äì there were 37 left. They managed to last 32, which raises the question why they are unable to consume their full quota of 50. This is the third successive occasion in this World Cup that Sri Lanka has failed to bat out their full quota, the first two being in the warm-up games. That is one area Sri Lanka needs to really work on for it‚Äôs a cardinal sin in ODI cricket not to use your full quota. One encouraging factor to emerge from the match was that Charith Asalanka and skipper Dasun Shanaka managed to spend time in the middle to score fifties. Asalanka has proved time and again that he is rock solid in the middle-order lending that stability which the team needs. As for Shanaka, he could breathe a bit easy having finally managed to come up with a half-century after failures in his past 17 innings. He was not at his best but the innings would give him a world of good for his confidence for the rest of the tournament.

newsArray.title: India gifted Asian Games cricket gold over Afghanistan by ranking rule
newsArray.content: Gifted an armchair ride by Asian Games organisers, India has taken gold in men‚Äôs cricket as the rain-hit T20 final against Afghanistan was decided by the superpower‚Äôs superior global ranking. Afghanistan, ranked 10th in the ICC‚Äôs T20 rankings versus world number one India, was left with silver on Saturday and powerless to do anything about it after rain halted the match when they were 112 for five after 18.2 overs of the first innings. With India unable to bat a minimum of five overs, and play was abandoned soon after 5 p.m. local time (09:00 GMT), leaving Ruturaj Gaikwad‚Äôs team to celebrate victory by default. Deciding results based purely on teams‚Äô global rankings is almost unheard of in cricket, let alone for finals in major tournaments. Most allow spare days so that deciders can be completed if rain washes out play in the original match. If no spare days are provided, a winner is generally declared via tie-breaking criteria based on a team‚Äôs performances within the tournament they are playing. Twenty20 cricket has been played at the Asian Games twice before, at Guangzhou 2010 and Incheon 2014, with Bangladesh and then Sri Lanka crowned men‚Äôs winners. Afghanistan were runners-up both times, but India did not take part. The rankings rule also helped India‚Äôs gold medal-winning women‚Äôs team reach the semifinals after rain washed out their quarterfinal against Malaysia. India went on to beat Sri Lanka by 19 runs to be crowned women‚Äôs champions last week. Rain also hit the men‚Äôs bronze medal playoff won by Bangladesh against Pakistan but held off long enough to at least ensure a contest between the teams.

newsArray.title: Marsh grasses and Kohli flowers: India take game one
creator: Greg Baum
newsArray.description: Australia will never know what might have happened if Mitch Marsh had taken a difficult catch from Virat Kohli. But afterwards, he stole the match away from them.
newsArray.content: For as long as Virat Kohli‚Äôs popped top-edged pull from Josh Hazlewood hung in the steamy Chepauk air, so did Australia‚Äôs suddenly alive prospects of upsetting India in this World Cup opener, making a distant memory of their pre-tournament woes and perhaps supplanting the host as the team to beat. It had happened here before. The crowd knew it; they gasped. If ‚Äì when ‚Äì the catch was taken, it would leave India, already reeling from a trio of top-order ducks, 4/20 in what would surely then be a vain pursuit of Australia‚Äôs admittedly modest 199. Its batting order this night was not as dependably deep as in recent years. But wicketkeeper Alex Carey and square leg Mitch Marsh, sprinting towards each other, had no time to establish right of way and a sliding Marsh dropped the catch. In the compounding way of these things, both had earlier made ducks on personally miserable nights. Hazlewood blamed no one. ‚ÄúI think it was Mitch‚Äôs catch and Carey got quite close in the end and might have just put Mitch off,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a dropped catch, one of those things that happened.‚Äù It‚Äôs not empirically demonstrable, of course, that this was the match in a moment. Hazlewood pooh-poohed the idea. ‚ÄúIt was quite early,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe still felt that new ball ‚Äì it was doing enough, whether it was in the air or off the wicket, (and) we knew that spin was going to be tough to play. Maybe not as tough as during the day. We certainly felt in the game for quite a while until the partnership grew and grew. They sort of batted us out of it.‚Äù Mitch Marsh after being dismissed. Credit: Getty Indeed, the reprieved Kohli was as mistake-free as only he can be ‚Äì and KL Rahul fell in alongside him ‚Äì although he eventually fell for a textbook 85. By then, he and Rahul had added 165 and paced their country to the threshold of a four-wicket victory. Rahul finished the match by handsomely driving Australian captain Pat Cummins over long off for six to strand himself on 97 not out, whereupon non-striker Hardik Pandya shook his head at the bittersweetness of it all. In the dewy monsoonal night, Australia‚Äôs makeshift spin pair Adam Zampa and Glenn Maxwell were unable to replicate the mesmerising mastery of India‚Äôs trio spinners in the afternoon. Moreover, the Indian bowlers as a team ‚Äì their quicks merit honourable mentions here, too ‚Äì had so restrained Australia that the batsmen in their turn could make haste slowly, and did. Rahul goes big. Credit: AP It made for a peculiarly downbeat game for these best of rivals, paling beside the pyrotechnics of the first three days. Australia‚Äôs 199 was fewer than South Africa had made in their last 20 overs against Sri Lanka in Delhi the night before. Admittedly, this was apples and pears ‚Äì Sri Lanka‚Äôs attack was feeble ‚Äì but this World Cup appears to be there for the bold to take. South Africa are Australia‚Äôs next opponent. The crowd figure was of a piece with the action. At 32,351, it was well short of the stadium‚Äôs 40,000 capacity. Not yet in the tournament has a stadium been full, though notionally every match has sold out. Cricket might be a religion in this country, but it belongs to an exclusive brethren. But there‚Äôs no mystery; it‚Äôs down to chronic disorganisation. Other than that 12-ball, three-wicket counterpunch at the top of India‚Äôs innings, this was a largely forgettable opening sally for Australia, in which their recent shortcomings were again exposed: inability to accelerate with the bat and lack of penetration in spin bowling. Hazlewood refuted the idea that the spin department was lacking, saying he regarded Maxwell in India as a frontliner, but conditions had militated against rather than for them this day. Australia, drawing on previous experience, had batted first in the expectation that the pitch would die and batting would become harder as the day wore on, but instead found that was at its most challenging in the afternoon sun. ‚ÄúIt was as extreme as it gets,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt was probably a good examination to get first up, against the best spinners in the tournament. Hopefully, it‚Äôll get a bit easier from hereon in.‚Äù From the early loss of Marsh, Australia always felt a wicket over budget. With verifiable batting only to No.7, they did not have the luxury of a wicket to throw away in the cause of a momentum-shifting blast as the Indian spinners wove their characteristic web around Australia. David Warner, Steve Smith and Marnus Labuschagne all toiled in vain to force the pace. When the squeeze became too much, Australia lost 5/30. Smith alone could be said to have been dismissed by an unplayable ball, a Ravindra Jadeja jaffa, straightening past his outside to bowl him. The Indian tweakers are a true ensemble too, each a virtuoso in a different key of their craft. In their collective 30 overs, they took 6/94. Loading If anything, the Australians‚Äô line-up was too orthodox for an era in which 50-over cricket has become a lengthier form of the T20 format. In theory, Marcus Stoinis would change that complexion, and Travis Head, too, if he can get a doctor‚Äôs certificate in time. If ever Australia needed a hand, it‚Äôs his broken one. India‚Äôs innings began as if the sun had gone to their heads. Ishan Kishan and Shreyas Iyer were caught from extravagant drives and captain Rohit Sharma was trapped by a break-back from Josh Hazlewood and after 12 balls, India were 3/2. If Australia had short-changed themselves when batting, suddenly they were trading in a whole new currency. But once Kohli was grassed and he and Rahul settled into their task, and as the dew fell and the crowd rose, Australia‚Äôs fangs were slowly drawn. None of the bowlers were embarrassed, but none notably troubled the Indian pair as their partnership grew. Australia prides itself on being a tournament team, rising to occasions, growing into the event. They will need to be now. They have at least eight more games at seven other venues. They know all will differ slightly, which means the Australians will have to adapt their tactics and outlook as they go. That includes the wisdom of batting first and the notion of what constitutes a playable score. ‚ÄúWe might come up against these conditions again throughout those eight games,‚Äù said Hazlewood. ‚ÄúWe might have to reassess and say 260 is a good score rather than 300 plus as we‚Äôve seen on some other grounds.‚Äù News, results and expert analysis from the weekend of sport sent every Monday. newsArray.title: Rain Stays Away in Chennai As India Beat Australia By Six Wickets in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023
newsArray.description: The Men in Blue begin their sojourn in the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 against Australia. But rainfall in the past few days in Chennai has posed a threat to this game? Will rain affect this match? Read below to get updates about Chennai weather.
newsArray.content: Despite rains in Chennai preceding the match, fortunately it didn't interrupt the game at any point. A complete was possible and in the end, India came out victorious beating Australia in their opening match of the campaign riding on the emphatic performances from KL Rahul and Virat Kohli. There has been no rain so far as the India vs Australia match in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 has gotten underway, with a bright sunny, sky up above. Players and fans would hope that this remains throughout and there is no rain interrupting this contest. The sun is out and the MA Chidambaram Stadium looks set to host this high-voltage contest. There has been no rain so far with less than two hours to go for the game to begin. Current Scenes of Chennai Stadium, The weather Looks Sunny üåà #INDvsAUS pic.twitter.com/IqUYcyDryf ‚Äî Haroon üèèüå† (@HaroonM33120350) October 8, 2023 The weather gods have been kind towards fans today as there has been no sign of rain in Chennai ahead of the India vs Australia match. It has rained in the city in the past few days which has posed a threat over this match as well. The weather at the moment is pretty sunny with patchy clouds. Sunny weather,patchy clouds #Chennai #IndvsAus pic.twitter.com/LlWCDk7eQ5 ‚Äî Chennai Weather-Raja Ramasamy (@chennaiweather) October 8, 2023 Good news for fans! There's no sign of rain in Chepauk so far hours before the India vs Australia ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 contest. Chennai has been witnessing unpredictable weather in the past few days but it is bright and sunny at the moment. Fans would hope the weather stays this way! It's bright & sunny at Chepauk. [Vimal Kumar] - Great news for cricket fans. pic.twitter.com/lnEHyNxSLb ‚Äî Johns. (@CricCrazyJohns) October 8, 2023 The MA Chidambaram Stadium in Chennai is set to host India's first match of the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023, against mighty Australia on October 8. The contest has been talked about a lot with home fans expecting India to put up a good show and get off to a winning start to their ICC Men's Cricket World Cup 2023 campaign. India recently did beat Australia in an ODI series and although that would give the Men in Blue some confidence, Rohit Sharma and his team would be well aware of how dangerous Australia really can be if their players fire in unison. However, there remains a rain threat that looms large over this contest in Chennai. India vs Australia ICC Cricket World Cup 2023, Chennai Weather Report: Check Out Rain Forecast and Pitch Report at M Chidambaram Stadium. The capital city has been experiencing inconsistent weather in the past few days and it casts a shadow of uncertainty over this high-octane match as well. An update on the Chennai weather provided by popular cricket commentator Harsha Bhogle might be a cause of worry for fans, who would have an eye on the sky as well today. Bhogle had taken to his official account on X, formerly Twitter, and wrote, "Bucketing down in Chennai...Very dark." There remains a possibility of this match being affected by rain. According to the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD), there is a 12-17% probability of rainfall in Chennai during the match hours. Moreover, there would be cloudy skies during the game. Fans would hope that should there be rain, it merely disrupts the contest for a while rather than washing it out. India could not have any warm-up match leading upto this match with rain washing out both their matches--against England and Netherlands. The Men in Blue would hope that the weather is fine when they take on Australia in this highly-anticipated CWC 2023 contest.

newsArray.title: Sachin Tendulkar, Virender Sehwag and Other Members of Cricket Fraternity React After India Defeat Australia By Six Wickets in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 Clash
newsArray.description: India started their campaign with an emphatic victory against Australia riding on the performances of Virat Kohli and KL Rahul. Elated former cricketers reacted on the memorable win.
newsArray.content: India won their first game of the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 against Australia at Chennai displaying a brilliant all-round performance with both ball and bat. First they squeezed Australia with the spinners crumbling them for only 199 runs and then during the chase, despite being in a dire situation, powered themselves out of it riding on the brilliant knocks of Virat Kohli and KL Rahul and won the match registering first points on the table. Sachin Tendulkar, Virender Sehwag, Irfan Pathan were elated by the performance and took to social media to react. I was surprised to see Australia bat first after winning the toss. Commendable performance by the Indian bowlers to restrict them to 199. Australia started well but I felt they missed a left-arm spinner on this surface. newsArray.title: Might have to change combinations as per different conditions: Rohit Sharma
newsArray.description: However, Rohit heaved a sigh of relief after India recovered from a precarious 2/3 to beat Australia by six wickets and begin their campaign in the showpiece on a positive note. CHENNAI: Rohit Sharma on Sunday admitted that the biggest challenge in front of his side would be to play in different conditions, and the Indian captain also did not rule out making changes in team combinations to suit the demands of a particular venue. However, Rohit heaved a sigh of relief after India recovered from a precarious 2/3 to beat Australia by six wickets and begin their campaign in the showpiece on a positive note. "That will be the biggest challenge moving forward because we will play in different conditions. (We) might have to change combinations too and as a team we are prepared to do that," said Rohit during the post-match presentation. Rohit was particularly pleased with the team's fielding. "Good feeling to come out on top. Magnificent, especially the fielding. The fielding was something we really put our effort on. It was a great effort. In conditions like this it can be tough sometimes. We knew there would be assistance for everyone. Seamers got reverse, spinners bowled in nice areas. All in all a great effort," he said. Rohit was one of the three top-order India batters to get out for a duck, and the skipper admitted to being nervous with the home team reeling at 2/3 in the second over. "Yes I was (nervous) to be honest. You don't want to start like that when chasing a target. Credit to Australia, but some loose shots there as well. But that happens, you want to get off the mark and score quickly in the powerplay." "But hats off to Virat and KL - the way they stuck out there to create a match-winning partnership," Rohit said. Australian captain Pat Cummins felt his team was 50 runs short of what could have been a challenging total. "At least 50-odd. It was tough, trying to defend anything under 200. It was a really good bowling attack and their spinners made it tough work out there. "I wasn't too upset (with just two spinners), we had 20 overs of spin but some more runs on the board would have made the difference," Cummins said. When asked about the drop catch by Mitchell Marsh early on in Kohli's innings, Cummins said, "I have already forgotten about it, it happens, 4/10 would have been a dream start. "Just one game out of nine, not too much to ponder about but there are some areas we need to get better." Arriving at the crease with his team in a spot of bother, Rahul said Kohli had advised him to play out that difficult period like they do in Test cricket. "Quite honestly, there weren't a lot of conversations (with Kohli). I thought I'd get a good shower and get a break. I was just trying to get my breath back." "Virat said there's a bit in the wicket, so play like Test cricket for a while. There was a bit of help for the pacers with the new ball, and then the spinners also," Rahul said. "In the last 15-20 overs, dew played a part and that helped quite a bit. The ball also skidded on better. However, it was a bit two-paced, it wasn't the easiest of wickets to bat on and it wasn't flat as well." "It was a good cricket wicket, bit for the batters and the bowlers. That's what you get in the south of India, especially in Chennai.
